children.value:
import remeta
import numpy as np
%load_ext autoreload
%autoreload 2
The two critical results of any computational model are 1) how well did the model fit (model evidence) and 2) what are the estimated parameters of the model. In this section, we cover both.
We load a builtin dataset and fit the default ReMeta model.

ds = remeta.load_dataset('default')
rem = remeta.ReMeta(optim_type2_gridsearch=False)
rem.fit(ds.stimuli, ds.choices, ds.confidence)

children.value: To access the results, it is recommended to first invoke the
The final parameter estimates are accessible via
In addition, each fitting stage (type 1 and type 2) can be accessed separately.
For each parameter estimate, ReMeta computes a standard error, reflecting the uncertainty in the parameter estimate:
The standard error is computed based on the Hessian matrix, which is the second derivative (i.e. curvature) of the log likelihood

children.html: ℓ(θ)\ell(\boldsymbol{\theta})ℓ(θ)
θ^\boldsymbol{\hat{\theta}}θ^

H(θ^)=∂2ℓ(θ)∂θ ∂θ⊤∣θ=θ^H(\boldsymbol{\hat{\theta}}) = \frac{\partial^2 \ell(\boldsymbol{\theta})}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta} \, \partial \boldsymbol{\theta}^\top} \Bigg|_{\boldsymbol{\theta} = \boldsymbol{\hat{\theta}}}H(θ^)=∂θ∂θ⊤∂2ℓ(θ)​∣∣​θ=θ^​
kkk
kkk
kkk

children.value: being the number of prameters. By inverting the Hessian, we get the covariance matrix:

children.html: Cov^(θ^)=(−H(θ^))−1\hat{\mathrm{Cov}}(\boldsymbol{\hat{\theta}}) = \left( - H(\boldsymbol{\hat{\theta}}) \right)^{-1}Cov^(θ^)=(−H(θ^))−1
SE^\hat{\mathrm{SE}}SE^
jjj
θ^j\hat{\theta}_jθ^j​

children.value: is the square root of the

children.html: jjj

children.value: -th diagonal element of the covariance matrix:

children.html: SE^(θ^j)=[Cov^(θ^)]jj\hat{\mathrm{SE}}(\hat{\theta}_j) = \sqrt{ \left[ \hat{\mathrm{Cov}}(\boldsymbol{\hat{\theta}}) \right]_{jj} }SE^(θ^j​)=[Cov^(θ^)]jj​​

children.value: The Hessian of the log-likelihood evaluated at

children.html: θ^\boldsymbol{\hat{\theta}}θ^

children.value: measures the local curvature of the likelihood surface at that point. A steeper curvature indicates that even small deviations from

children.html: θ^\boldsymbol{\hat{\theta}}θ^

children.value: are inconsistent with the observed data and thus higher certainty about our particular parameter estimate. In contrast, a flatter curvature a flatter curvature indicates that the log-likelihood changes only gradually near

children.html: θ^\boldsymbol{\hat{\theta}}θ^

children.value: , meaning that a wider range of parameter values is consistent with the data and we are less certain about our particular parameter estimate.

When the model fit includes group-level data (with random or fixed effects), a third level in the result object becomes relevant, which separates subject-level and group-level information. For this purpose, we load a built-in dataset with three participants:

children.value: Group-level parameters are first fitted at an individual level, to provide suitable initial values for the group-level estimate. The result object always contains information for both levels, accessible as follows.
In the case, the type 2 level was not fitted at the group level and thus the group-level parameters only include type 1 parameters.
Since the type 2 level did not include group-level parameters,
ReMeta is fundamentally based on a frequentist framework and uses maximum likelihood estimation to estimate parameters.
Likelihood at the type 1 stage is the probability of decisions

children.html: DDD
xxx
θ1\boldsymbol{\theta_1}θ1​

children.value: . Maximum likelihood estimation tries to find the set of paratemers

children.html: θ^1\boldsymbol{\hat{\theta}_1}θ^1​

children.value: that maximize the likelihood under the sampling distribution

children.html: f(D∣θ1,x)f(D\mid \boldsymbol{\theta_1}, x)f(D∣θ1​,x)
θ^1=argmax⁡θ1f(D∣x,θ1)\boldsymbol{\hat{\theta}_1} = arg\max_{\boldsymbol{\theta_1}} f(D\mid x,\boldsymbol{\theta_1})θ^1​=argθ1​max​f(D∣x,θ1​)

children.value: Likelihood at the type 2 stage is the probability of reported confidence ratings

children.html: CCC
yyy
θ2\boldsymbol{\theta_2}θ2​
θ^2=argmax⁡θ2f(C∣y,θ2)f(y)\boldsymbol{\hat{\theta}_2} = arg\max_{\boldsymbol{\theta_2}} f(C\mid y,\boldsymbol{\theta_2})f(y)θ^2​=argθ2​max​f(C∣y,θ2​)f(y)

children.value: Likelihoods are computed for the type 1 and type 2 stage separately and are represented as such in the result object:

print(f'Type 1 log likelihood (overall): {result.type1.loglik:.3f}')
print(f'Type 1 log likelihood (per sample): {result.type1.loglik_per_sample:.3f}')
print(f'Type 2 log likelihood (overall): {result.type2.loglik:.3f}')
print(f'Type 2 log likelihood (per sample): {result.type2.loglik_per_sample:.3f}')

children.value: Higher likelihoods indicate better fits. If different studies are compared, it is best to assess the likelihood
In Addition, ReMeta reports the Akaike information criterion (AIC) and the Bayesian information criterion (BIC):

children.html: AIC=2k−2log⁡L(θ^)\mathrm{AIC} = 2k-2 \log L(\boldsymbol{\hat{\theta}})AIC=2k−2logL(θ^)
kkk

children.value: is the number of parameters and

children.html: L(θ^)L(\boldsymbol{\hat{\theta}})L(θ^)

children.value: is the likelihood for the estimated parameters

children.html: θ^\boldsymbol{\hat{\theta}}θ^
BIC=klog⁡n−2log⁡L(θ^)\mathrm{BIC} = k \log n-2 \log L(\boldsymbol{\hat{\theta}})BIC=klogn−2logL(θ^)
nnn

children.value:
print(f'Type 1 AIC (overall): {result.type1.aic:.2f}')
print(f'Type 1 AIC (per sample): {result.type1.aic_per_sample:.4f}')
print(f'Type 2 AIC (overall): {result.type2.aic:.2f}')
print(f'Type 2 AIC (per sample): {result.type2.aic_per_sample:.4f}\n')

print(f'Type 1 BIC (overall): {result.type1.bic:.2f}')
print(f'Type 1 BIC (per sample): {result.type1.bic_per_sample:.4f}')
print(f'Type 2 BIC (overall): {result.type2.bic:.2f}')
print(f'Type 2 BIC (per sample): {result.type2.bic_per_sample:.4f}')

children.value: Here, lower AIC and BIC values indicate better fits.
If a group-level model was fitted to a stage, the result objects contains both the model evidence of the subject-level fit and the group-level fit for each:

for s in range(result2.nsubjects):
    print(f'[subject {s}] Subject-level log likelihood: {result2.type1.subject.loglik[s]:.2f}')

jupyter_data.name: stdout
jupyter_data.text:
[subject 0] Subject-level log likelihood: -326.13
[subject 1] Subject-level log likelihood: -333.80
[subject 2] Subject-level log likelihood: -361.38

children.value:
for s in range(result2.nsubjects):
    print(f'[subject {s}] Group-level log likelihood: {result2.type1.group.loglik[s]:.2f}')

jupyter_data.name: stdout
jupyter_data.text:
[subject 0] Group-level log likelihood: -326.14
[subject 1] Group-level log likelihood: -334.08
[subject 2] Group-level log likelihood: -361.86

children.value: Note that the group level log likelihood is expected to be higher than the subject-level log likelihood. It is precisely the goal of group-level fits to avoid overfitting to individual subjects.
